area_name: Roadside Formation (Red Fleet State Park Area)

content.description: Short and nice, just like me. Start on the right side of the main face. Right hand on the closer of the two vertical sloping holds, left hand on low on a good crimp. move up through iron weathered slopy crimps to and an easy top out.
content.location: An easy stop if you are heading to Red Fleet. This boulder is on the right side of the road in a field across from the entrance to Steinaker State Park. Multiple problems on the single boulder.

content.description: Nothing super hard here, just some committing moves on dirty chinle sandstone. Start with some good hands in pockets along a low seam, and a good right foot in a lower pocket, then pull some dynamic moves straight up and right on the face, looking for more pockets for hands and feet.  Top out with no hands (scary) and walk off the back.
content.location: To the South/Southeastern end of the large, soot-stained cave, look for the face covered with pockets before the trail to the backside of the formation.  Also look for the large spiders and spiderwebs residing in aforementioned pockets.  This is why me and a friend dubbed this the Spider Wall.  Ugggghhhhh.  More bouldering to be had here for people with stronger wills, thicker calluses, any sort of pads, and less of an aversion to spiders.

content.description: Was messing around here on my way through.  This cool feature is just right of "Layback and Relax" near the top of the wall.  I didnt go all the way to the horizontal crack because I was alone (no one to move the pad), but with a couple pads and spotters this could be a pretty cool problem! Hard to start if shorter than 6'0".  May need a boost.
content.protection: 2 pads 2 spotters OR one really big pad and a really attentive spotter. Also due to the angle of the lower slab section you'd probably want to down climb about half way before jumping off.
content.location: Upper formation, just right of Lay Back and Relax (on the way to it).

content.description: Good warm up bouldering for the whole area, and a good place to test how well you can handle grainy sandstone.  Scale the wavy slab on the southern side of the Cavemen Boulders from the very bottom.  Scarce handholds and decent feet make this route good for practicing slab moves.  Move to the eastern arete of the top boulder and shimmy your way to the top from there.  Walk off down the back.
content.location: On the south end of the Roadside Formation, look for two boulders forming a cave with a smaller rock to top it all off; this will be just to the left of a much larger cave with soot stains covering the ceiling, and we've taken to calling this formation the Cavemen Boulders.  There are some harder problems here for people who actually bring pads (unlike us) and don't mind getting torn up on the sandstone.

content.description: Straightforward crack up the very middle of the Middle Boulder.  Start on the Southwestern face, in front of the medium sized sagebrush.  Using hand jams and side pulls, work your way up the crack and to the right, with some good feet on the perpendicular crack running through the center of the face.  Top out, and then walk off the back and to your left, lowering to another, smaller boulder and then to the ground.
content.location: The Middle Boulder is located just Northwest of Caveman Boulders, 20 meters up the road from the large cave.  (check pictures)

content.description: Layback and mantle through an odd 5.8 start (the only move on the route above 5.5-5.6) to gain lower angled terrain.  Follow the thin crack/flake for 10 ft to a straight-in hand crack angling up and left.  Follow this 5.5 crack up through the slot to belay. Walk off to the south towards Brush Creek.
content.protection: Bottom belay stance is on steep and soft clay, protect belayer with #3-4 camalots.  Upper belay takes #1-3.5 camalots or larger nuts/hexes.  For route: a few smaller nuts and a few handsize or smaller cams.
content.location: This route is the obvious low-angle ramp with a crack in it as seen from the road.

content.description: Large freestanding boulder with a split in the middle creating both a left facing and right facing arete.
content.protection: I did it with one pad, multiple would be advised with a spotter.
content.location: Directly off of 191 past the turn off for Red Fleet state park on the right. Turn right onto a dirt road with a very tight road guard entrance. Boulder is down the road a bit and obvious.

content.description:
This arched roof looks really sweet and the crux looks pretty tough.  The start follows a low angle ramp and corner up to an almost vertical/slightly overhung offwidth section, then a layback crack in the roof traverses left about 30 ft.  After that you can move around the roof and follow another short crack/scramble to the top of the formation.  For rope drag reasons I would belay at the end of the traverse, then make the short climb to the top.  I've made it part-ways through the roof traverse but never completed the climb.

*This route isn't actually named and I have no idea how accurate the rating is.  If anyone has info feel free to email me and I will update this!  Thanks
content.protection: Handsize or smaller gear on the ramp, #3.5 camalot or bigger for the crux, then handsize pieces in the roof for the traverse over.
content.location: About 50 yards left of Layback and Relax.

content.description: Not a traverse in the technical sense of the word, but a fun V0 nonetheless and a decent scramble up some crumbly rock.  Start on the eastern boulder, on the opposite side from Paleo Diet.  Make your way up the easy holds to the first boulder's peak.  Lower yourself off the arete to the next boulder, then work your way up the easy holds on the Northeast side of the top boulder until you reach the tippy-top.  Voila!  Now scramble down the walk-off on the backside.
content.location: On the south end of the Roadside Formation, look for two boulders forming a cave with a smaller rock to top it all off; this will be just to the left of a much larger cave with soot stains covering the ceiling, and we've taken to calling this formation the Cavemen Boulders. There are some harder problems here for people who actually bring pads (unlike us) and don't mind getting torn up on the sandstone.

content.description: The chains are at the top of the cave near Deer Creek just north of Red Fleet by the boulder field off the right side of the Road as you're heading north. Follow the edge of the cave, which is fairly juggy at first and severely overhung. The crux comes when you have to dyno up to a two-finger pocket, smear off of that and work up to a stretched out sandy sloper. Try not to fall for the first ten feet or so, you might deck, it's that overhung. If you're worried about it bring a crash pad.
content.protection: Just chains at the top for now, still bolting it.
content.location: Deer Creek just past the Red Fleet Res. Turnout, take the dirt road in it's the dark cave in the otherwise red/brown sandstone.

pathTokens: Roadside Formation (Red Fleet State Park Area)
